data.title: Add "Open Folder" menu on Linux and Windows
data.body: On Linux and Windows a open dialog can only choose either files or folders, and never both, so we have to provide a separate menu item to open folders.

data.title: Remember last window dimensions
data.body:
When you open Atom directly from Finder (instead of the cli) the default window position is always used. This PR stores the last used window dimensions and uses them when opening a new window.

Fixes #1269 
Waiting on atom/atom-shell#227

data.title: maximum call stack size exceeded
data.body:
I get these errors pretty frequently:

```
Uncaught RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/emissary/lib/behavior.js:44
```

EDIT: Restarting atom fixes this, of course.  Thankfully, I'm still able to save my files too.  I just can't really move the cursor or select text anymore.

data.title: Move functionality from Project to Workspace Part II
data.body:
A continuation of https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/1844

There was a deserialization problem. Workspace stores editor instances using `Workspace::addEditor`. But when a workspace is deserialized, editors are created before the `atom.workspace` variable is created, so `Editor` can't call `atom.workspace.addEditor`. This worked before because project is separate from editor creation.

It makes me think storing editors on Workspace isn't a good idea, but I'm not sure of a better place to store them. An alternative is to decouple Pane deserialization from Workspace deserialization.

data.title: Make auto-updating more resilient
data.body:
Previously menu items and events were only available from the window that initiated the update method. It was :poop:. This PR creates an AutoUpdateManager class that holds the update state and handles notifying AtomWindows of changes to the AutoUpdate processes.

Fixes #1834, #1846

data.title: Opening a file from a folder which contains many files is slow
data.body:
Halp ticket:
- support/7ca5bdc2b92d11e39039cbba6d0f0bfc

> I am opening a single python file inside a folder that contains about 29,000 files.
> ...
> I'm working on a python script to iterate through about 30,000 HTML files in a folder. So when I typed in atom compare_html.py at the command line, the atom window would open up and no file was open in the editor.
> 
> What I neglected to add to the feedback (I sent the feedback only after waiting a short while) that after two or three minutes, atom would open up the file in question and all the files would be listed in the directory tree. So it took atom a while, apparently, to load and parse the contents of the folder.
> 
> My expectation as a user would be to on open the file in the editor and not the folder. If it was going to open the folder anyway, maybe spawn that off in a different process?

I just gave this a try by creating a folder with 30000 html files (9kb each) and that does seem to be true -- Atom took a few minutes to open a file from the folder. 

File > Open completed immediately with no content displayed in the editor, but I noticed that an AtomHelper process took 100% of the CPU and starting taking more and more memory. Just after the process took 1GB of memory, a new Atom Window was shown with the contents of the file and 30k items in the tree view.

data.title: Autoupdating is confusing for some users
data.body:
Every now and then users ask "How do I update to a new version?" when we tell them "Does this problem still happen in Atom 0.84.0" (or whatever the latest version is).

It seems that it's not obvious to users that Atom has an in-app autoupdater (e.g. [1](support/eb12f796ba7911e39856e409c8ca78d6), [2](support/fc044afeb43511e391782230e8b171e6)) and when exactly it checks for updates (does it happen automatically? do they need to do something?). 

Also, sometimes the "Check for update" menu option is not visible, and sometimes it is -- I can't seem to figure out what exactly affects this (I don't see it at the moment). The menu option seems to vanish after I open a new window (cmd-shift-N).

Finally, it seems that some users are having problems with the autoupdater and it's showing errors for them ([3](support/4582134cb67911e39519cd1b52378874)):

![a88737ba-bc23-11e3-8c8c-19b963e17e22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2622407/b64097b6-bcaf-11e3-993c-9bf1c3eed803.png)

data.title: Move functionality from Project to Workspace
data.body:
Openers and editors were still being stored in Project. This moves the specs and the variables themselves over to Workspace.

Moving Buffers over is something else we could do, but I'm not sure how that fits with our multi-project plans.

data.title: I no longer receive Atom updates
data.body:
I was lamenting this to @thedaniel and @nathansobo a few days ago, and I'm wondering if this problem is getting to be more serious. 

I was running 0.76.0 and couldn't update to 0.79.0:

![screen shot 2014-03-28 at 12 19 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/64050/2610771/45b69074-bb90-11e3-96c0-1b8ecfaeb791.png)

I manually downloaded 0.79.0 and happily chugging along. I discovered now that there's a 0.83.0 release. 

The file menu tells me it is "Downloading update...", but I never see the blue squirrel, and subsequent restart attempts don't bring me a new editor. 

Launching with `atom -f` does tell me the download finished:

```
[master] ~/.atom/packages/documentation-tools $ atom -f
[57544:0403/172403:WARNING:dns_config_service_posix.cc(188)] dns_config has unhandled options!
2014-04-03 17:24:04.101 Atom[57544:507] App load time: 142ms
[57546:0403/172404:INFO:renderer_main.cc(227)] Renderer process started
[57544:0403/172405:INFO:CONSOLE(18)] "Window load time: 785ms", source: /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-bootstrap.js (18)
2014-04-03 17:24:41.068 Atom[57544:12d03] Download completed to: file:///Users/garentorikian/Library/Application%20Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.Oicp5uh/download
```

But I guess the temp directory cleans up after itself, because the download is no longer there.

data.title: Allow backspace to beginning of word on first line
data.body:
Steps to reproduce issue:
-  Create a file with the text (leading whitespace before the `var`):

```
    var sort
```
- Put cursor before the `v`
- Press `alt-delete` (editor:backspace-to-beginning-of-word)
- Whitespace isn't deleted

data.title: Don't call Config::save when setting defaults
data.body:
Previously `Config::setDefaults` called `Config::update` which calls `Config::save`.

This was being called roughly ~30 times during startup since many packages have default values, adding about ~30ms to startup.

I think `Config::update` was being called for the emitting of an `update` event so instead just emit it directly from `Config::setDefaults`.

data.title: Problems controlling which grammar is selected for .rb files
data.body:
There are two grammars that match `.rb` files, one from `language-ruby` and another from `language-ruby-on-rails`. Currently, whichever package is loaded first always wins. 
- We should change this to favor packages loaded later.
- Even so, it's completely arbitrary that these packages load in the order they do. How will we handle this kind of ambiguity in general?

support/6a53d248b5e111e3984bcab59a26b5c6#C2

data.title: Frequently excessive CPU, memory consumption
data.body:
Over the last few weeks I’ve noticed that Atom is frequently consuming what I would consider a fairly large amount of resources. It seems that just having a single window open, without even openning any tabs/buffers, will predictably open a couple of (usually two, sometimes three) "Atom Helper" processes which will between them consume ~100% of one CPU core worth of activity:

Sometimes this is heavily weighted towards a single Atom Helper process (~100% on one, single digit percentage on the others—as the above screenshot shows), but other times it’s split fairly evenly across a number of Atom Helper processes (e.g. ~30-40% on each of three processes).

As you can see from the screenshot, this is occuring with the github/github repo, with no files open. I don’t think it’s due to any search indexing/scanning processes or anything that I imagine happen when you first open a directory, since the activity continues predictably even if leaving the window open for like 20 minutes.

The memory consumption is also frequently the top item in my list (again this is without having any buffers open).

![atom-memory-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/296432/2603699/427dcd22-bb32-11e3-8373-1f290c4bd0ab.png)

FWIW I’ve tried leaving Atom open with no open buffers in much smaller folders/repos than github/github too, and there doesn’t appear to be any discernible difference in CPU or memory consumption.

I’m not really sure if this issue helps at all, since it doesn’t really suggest a concrete bug or problem that has a clearly actionable fix. I’m sorry about that, but I felt like this was worth bringing up :gift_heart:
